them to be opurcula of Ammonites;_ <u>Porpitae nummulares</u> by
Stobaeus <sup>2</sup> and Bromell <sup>3</sup>, who seem to have regarded them as representing
the disks of the existing Porpita,_ of <u>Helicites</u> and <u>Operculites</u> by
Guettard<sup>4</sup>, who considered then as opercula of Gastropods;_
of <u>Discolithes</u> by Portis<sup>5</sup>, who supposed them to be skeletons
of mollusks; of <u>Madreporites</u> by Deluc, and of <u>Milleporites</u> by
Faujas de St <s>Pond</s> Fond, whose idea of their nature is sufficiently indicated 
by the names they assigned to them

<u>Note</u> 
[ 1. De Couchis minus notis, 1739 (fide D'Archiac & Haime) and App.Phytol.
T. Coll, 1764 (fide Rupert Jones).

2 Dissertatio epist ad M. Grothaus de nummulo Brattenburgensi, 1732;
Opera petrefactorum, 1752 Opuculis p 6 (fide D'Archiac & Haime)

3 De Nummulo Brattenburgico, in Act. litt
